item.title: Preventing Factory Explosions by (Safely) Blowing Stuff Up
item.description: Jenny Chao, who tinkered in the garage as a child, is a mechanical engineer specializing in industrial explosions for a commercial property insurance company.
item.author: As told to PATRICIA R. OLSEN

item.title: Want Co-Workers to Vote Your Way? Then Stop Pestering Them
item.description: Studies have shown that people tend to consider unsolicited advice as a threat to their free will, and they will often protest by doing the opposite.
item.author: By GAVAN FITZSIMONS

item.title: Deirdre Quinn: If a Meeting Starts at 9, Be There at 8
item.description: Ms. Quinn, chief of the women’s fashion site Lafayette 148 New York, says her pet peeve is lateness. When a meeting starts, she says, she closes the door.
item.author: By ADAM BRYANT

item.title: When It Comes to Success, Age Really Is Just a Number
item.description: A new study points to a combination of personality, persistence and luck as leading to success, and scientists say that those same forces are at play at all levels of a discipline.
item.author: By BENEDICT CAREY

item.title: Bossy vs. Buddy: Two Leadership Styles, Each With Its Place
item.description: Some managers lead by dominating employees; others try to win them over. But the most effective leaders deploy the style best suited to the situation.
item.author: By PHYLLIS KORKKI

item.title: Antique Teddy Bears and an Artist’s Trash: An ‘Art Dork’ in Her Element
item.description: Emily Weiss earned an art degree, but instead of becoming a starving artist, she got an insurance broker’s license and assesses works by major art world figures.
item.author: As told to PATRICIA R. OLSEN

item.title: We’re hiring three journalists to help shape opinion coverage at The New York Times
item.description: In an editor role we're looking for a person who defines editing broadly, from written columns to interactive stories and reader engagement. We also seek two visual journalists to join the team.

item.title: Groped at a Party by a Colleague. Then You Become His Boss.
item.description: A woman did not report a harrowing incident involving a male colleague at a company holiday party. Then, a twist: That colleague became her subordinate.
item.author: By ROB WALKER

item.title: Austin McChord of Datto: It’s Not Awesome Till It’s Awesome
item.description: Austin McChord, C.E.O. of the data protection company Datto, says he resists the trend of automatically handing out praise and instead saves it for exceptional achievements.
item.author: By ADAM BRYANT

item.title: The New York Times is looking for a Deputy Video Editor
item.description: We’re hiring the best talent to shape our on the ground and original reporting, experiment with new forms of video, and launch a new slate of shows and series.
